reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game, and for the first thirty minutes, I did. The problem is that after about an hour, the game plateaus. You're doing the same things over and over again, and there's no end game or advancement past a certain point.

So why did I log three hours, making it impossible to get a refund for the game?

Because I stupidly kept going for two hours trying to see if eventually anything would change, only to discover after three hours that nothing did. The years progressed, but the tasks (drag canvas here, drag painter there) never varied or progressed in any meaningful way. I maxed out a few painters, then they died and the process started over again maxing out their most skillful apprentices. Repeat ad nauseum. I made it up to the late 1500s before throwing in the towel.

The housing decoration might be something to work towards, but all the housing stuff has stats, so if you want to max your stats you'll just end up with the same room pattern repeated over and over with some different furniture. Similarly, the furniture has stats, so there's little point in buying anything but the nicest stuff, unless you're some kind of gaming masochist.

I guess the main problem is that there is no meaningful progression in this game. It's got one, maybe two hours of decent playtime in it before the repetition becomes too dull and tedious to continue. (Two hours is pretty generous, I think.)

The art style is gorgeous, and it's fun to see the little pixel masterpieces, but they vanish quickly. A gallery of paintings you've unlocked over various playthroughs would be a great way to showcase all the work that went into those little pixel gems and give the overarching gameplay some purpose. Even just making it possible to buy blank canvases to make paintings purely for decoration rather than at a patron's request would be nice. Then you could hang your favorite masterpieces in your guild home. Just *something* to add value to the game's price tag, which is a bit high for the current content.

I hope that the game might be improved upon in future updates. I don't know if it will, but it would certainly be worth revisiting in the future if the dev is active and updates are planned.
voteText: 291 of 325 people (90%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I'm a really big art history person, so when I saw this game I was excited. Playing and installing it was easy and simple, it runs on almost nothing. Before playing it I knew nothing of the flash games and beta builds, I bought it on the art relationship alone. I'm not a real big gamer.

The game is probably not worth the price it is pushing now, I would dump it into the under $5 category. After about two hours I had pretty much capped out the usability of the game and it just turns into a repetitive task exercise of 1) resting the artist 2) taking an order 3) placing an artist  on a travel roster/canvas slot. There is really not much to it, on maxing out your artists or training new ones.

However, the game does use actual art movements and terms and features potential pupils all the way up through the 1620s. The pixel paintings depict actual works of art from the time period and are very on point. Decorations are limited but they're really the only goal you shoot for. I was attached to my first few artists when they died, but after that it becomes less fun and more of a drag. I'll probably play this every now and again but it was definitely not worth the price I paid. New features should of been added for Steam like relationships or allowing your artists to do other tasks that actually affect the core gameplay outside the monotone cycle.

reviewText:
Loved the free version[www.kongregate.com] of the game, finally it's released on Steam! And now it's clear what took so long- this is an immensely expanded and lovingly polished version that adds a multitude of content and mechanics to the game.

There's different artistic styles now, large projects like painting churches, management and ability to hire new artists, oh and you can expand and personalize your home as well. Do I need to mention that the entire game is gorgeous? I'm sure you are aware. What you can't see from the screenshots is the amount of polish this game has. Every click feels and sounds great, the user interface is helpful and intuitive, and you have to hear the little guys squeak when you pick them up!

Basically, if you enjoyed the demo, you will love this game and waste way too much time in it, no doubt.

reviewText:
A cute little game but lacks depth for replayability. I'd like to see it move at a slightly slower pace over a shorter time period, some more personality in the painters, and some higher stakes for the decisions you make. Once you learn the mechanics it's very easy to have a stable of 4-5 painters at 100 skill (and a full back-burner of apprentices to fill the ranks) churning through everything that comes their way, and money ceases to be a problem. The random events don't add much challenge or offer any interesting choices, and I never saw much reason to take on grand works, since you don't lose prestige for turning them down. Here are some things I think could turn this into a great game:

- Slow the pace a bit
- Make great works higher stakes (lose prestige when you turn them down, but gain a lot when you complete them)
- More interactivity between painters (rivalries or conflicting personalities?)
- Make events more interesting (opportunity to gain lots of prestige / money at great risk, rival houses trying to poach your painters, painting in a certain style becomes ridiculously lucrative or punishing, etc.)
- Greater quantity and more diverse items
- Copies of prestige items should grant diminishing returns (beacuse a house chock-a-block with statues looks silly)

reviewText:
Pretty fun little game, and I do mean little.

There is enough content for a few hours of very enjoyable gameplay, as you listen to the sounds track and push and pull your little art slaves around you get a lot of satisfaction as you watch your Florins grow and you build up and customize your little painters guild.

There are a couple of different maps that add minor bonuses to certian aspects of the game, increased florins from sales for example. There are a few random events in game that add aspects of uncertainy; illnesses can spread, homosexual guild members might be attacked or, you might be asked to pay of a gambling debt or two.

These random events can be fairly impactful during the beginning of the game, but once you have a larger guild the minor events become negligible, as you'll have enough florins and people to quickly hire and retrain new master artists.

However, after you've added your third/forth building and have 100+ prestige the game doesn't offer much else, at 100 prestige it seems you've hit the max level of rich customers and going over that is just to provide a buffer from prestige loss if you have all your artists out on a larger project.

All in all its a neat little casual game. I'd wish there was a bit more content. But I'm overall happy with the price and the amount of gameplay that comes with it.

reviewText:
This game should be priced under a buck or offered online while paid for by ads. In fact, there already is an online version you can play, and the additional mechanics here really don't amount to much.

The idea is great, and I really wish the designer expanded on it. Unfortunately, he didn't. The game leaves a ton to be desired. You generically train artists, recruit generic artists, paint generic paintings, buy generic furniture...

...and just do this over and over again to keep your painter guild alive as one generation passes away before the next. The game lasts until a certain point where you reach a high score.

If you're a real life artist, you'll probably get a kick out of the game for a few hours and will like the novelty, but beyond that, it's really not worth much.

reviewText: It is a very good game, especially considering its price and budget. It has some annoying features, such as having your painter to sleep before going on a journey (and the first couple times I just clicked on an envelope that shows up no matter if he or she is tired or not), but I played all the way into the 1650s without being bored even for a minute. My guild had its ups and downs with painters dying, prosecuted for homosexuality and arrested and my gameplay was well diversified I'd say.\n\nIt is a simple game and a cheap one - therefore it should be judged accordingly. If it was to cost, let's say, 20 Euros, than it would definitely not be worth recommending, but considering the price (including the Steam sale), I'd say it's pretty good, especially if you are interested in art and its history.

reviewText: This game is really cool. If you appreciate history, art, and management sims, this game is the perfect little time-waster for you. You can aquire great painters of the renaissance like Da Vinci or, umm, I don't know who else but there are plenty of historical references to keep it interesting. I really love the art style, my favorite place to set up the guild is in Venice on the water. There are lots of mechanics that you can progressively access as the game goes on, like using the camera obscura to study and increase your artist's level with, but it is constantly driven by the basic needs of your painters and customers that also become increasingly more difficult to deal with. So it doesn't get boring too fast, unless you are a god a management sims. That being said, there are a lot of things this game needs to increase its replayability, such as achievements. Luckily, it seems as if the devs are still working on the game and adding things to it, which is great. Overall, if you took the time to click on the game's home page to check it out, scrolled all the way down to the review section, and happened to read this one long and overdrawn comment all the way to the end, stop wasting your time: this game is perect for you!

reviewText: Painter's Guild is a simplified take on the management genre, wherein you micromanage painters to fulfill orders, mix up paint and sleep. You start with just one painter, and have the opportunity to expand your studio in order to hire new painters and buy more furniture that will help your painters out. That said, you don't have much of a primary goal in this game outside of buying the best furniture or simply expanding your studio until you grow bored of it, which is a shame because it grows samey and tiresome within a few hours.\n\nPainter's Guild is a fun, little game but I would not recommend buying it full price, simply because you likely won't get much time out of it. Definitely worth a shot on sale!

reviewText:
As an artist myself I thought this game looked pretty interesting. I never believed I would fall in love with it! It's beautiful style and ease of gameplay makes it a one of a kind. You even can hire famous artists like my 2nd favorite Leonardo DaVinci. (My 1st being a tie with Monet and Van Gogh.) I love that you can name your first charater whatever you wish, so I named him Bob Ross, and boy can Bob paint. lol

At first the playthrough was hard as I didn't fully understand the changes in style, and I just went and painted everything nearly one style. That playthrough did not last very long at all. My second went much better, although I still had no idea how to get rid of all the furniture. ( I now know a tip and plan to put it in use when next I play, which shall be very soon.) There were a few glitches, floating painters, issues with a painter not being able to make paint, but I went along with it anyway. What can I say, I'm a fellow artist and understand some of the things happening in the game. The sacrifice of sleep for work is real, as well as needing to study technique and how the visual world works.

In hindsight, if I didn't pay $3.12 for this game I would gladly have paid more. I'm in love. 9/10

reviewText:
This is actually my first review on Steam as I feel quite torn about this game.

On the one hand it's wonderful, the animations and sprite characters are charming, the music is up-beat and cheery (if, at times, a bit 18th Century, as opposed to Renaissance) and the gameplay is both addicting and fun!

On the other hand, all of this is only true for about two hours, because the whole thing lacks depth and content, and this is such a shame. Right now, it feels like a really well polished Beta game, with all the trimings but lacking that last bounty of extra content and final features.

The game tries (and succeeds) to be like the 'Tycoon' games of yore, but whereas those got harder and deeper as the game went on, this just stays the same. There's no extra challenge, all you can do is expand your guild for the sake of expanding, and have more adorable characters just because you can.

The furniture is a nice touch but there's not nearly enough of it, and it'd be nice for the whole 'homosexual' mechanic to have something beyond just the random chance of a death penatly. Maybe other artists could become each others' romantic muses or the like? Leading to increased stats but higher risk of being found out?

Right now, the fundaments of this game are brilliant, but it didn't have nearly enough content to keep me going for more than a few hours. If the developers make more challenge and cosmetic features (as they seem to be doing) then this really will be a first-rate game! As it stands I still recommend it to people, believing that more content is to come! :D
voteText: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you would've told me that I would love living the life of a Renaissance painter and running a huge painting business, I would've called you nuts. That is until I started playing Painters Guild, an adorable and addictive Business simulator. You will go from rags to much nicer rags as you begin to expand your colorful empire. Hiring new painters, expanding your shop, and decorating it with all sorts of useful items. The real fun for me in the game is getting the right painters for the right jobs, as taste change and customers demand a style. This is not only tricky but challenging if you only have certain kinds of painters. On top of all that Painters guild is a game that constantly keeps you busy, you won't sit idly by and watch them paint. You must manage your paints, endurance, bills, and most importantly the mastery of your painters skills. Each painter requires training and dedication to see them reach their full potential. While Paints Guild could use more polish in the options/tutorial department, I felt the good far out weighed the inconvenience of such things. So grab your funny hats and paint brushes and start up your very own guild!

I made a video review to show off some of the features and gameplay of this game!
https://youtu.be/6SPe3yeUNa0
I hope you enjoy!
Martyr

reviewText:
Painter's Guild is a little management, simulation, time management game. If you can get it at a lowered price it's worth it, given that you like games in that spectrum at all of course.
For such a small game in retro pixel graphic style it's rather complex. You can change the look of your painters to your liking with a dresser, you can decorate & furnish the rooms which increases the comfort for the painters, improves their skilling options & elevates the prestige of the guild, which then attracts richer clients. The painters you hire have a quite complex personality as well, there are two traits, both painting related which make the painter either faster painting, quicker skilling, healthier, easier to get into trouble & prison, painting more beautifully or changing quicker the initial painting style ... Besides of painting at the easels painters can also work outside the guild on murals, which pays better but is strenous enough to even kill your painters. There are three options to hire new painters, from cheapest & immediately arriving to most expensive & requiring some time for the painter to arrive & you're also able to hire some of the greatest painters of that time like Leonardo daVinci & Michelangelo Buonarotti. You hire the painters at a very young age, often as teenagers, after having some training at the guild they go on a journey, come back & skill further, can become a master painter, become even more skilled, age, get gray hair, become ill & die. In that respect it is quite a depressing game, the time is flowing, the masters which you trained & nurtured over the in game years are just gone one day & your guild is left without them & may not be able to provide paintings anymore of similiar quality, unpaid apprentices may even leave the guild & you will be left with the remaining handful of journeymen.

I noticed only one bug so far. Sometimes the easel with the painting gets stuck somewhere, making all clicks irresponsive. Though i was able to come out of that bug without loosing the progress, it's still unnerving.

Overall highly recommended.

reviewText:
Alright. Painters Guild. I'm a big fan of management games and simulators. This one looked pretty cool, so I went for it.

After playing for 4½ hours, I've seen everything this game has to offer.

It's not a big game, or a complex game, and there isn't much depth to it..

Honestly, spending 4½ hours with it might be longer than you'd want to. The systems get very repetitive, and I have a hard time putting a finger on what made me keep playing.

I guess it's very soothing. The soundtrack is very nice, the artstyle is cool, and I like the way the paintings look in the 8-bit artstyle.

Spending 8-10€ on it now is probably too much for you. You probably won't get more than 3 hours out of it before you get seriously bored, but it's a cool idea, and it's almost well executed. I just wish there were more things to do in the game.

As it is, you just assign painters to painting that you get hired to do. Then you train them, and make paint for the paintings... You just swap the painters around and you do an ungodly amount of clicking and dragging.


I sound negative, but all in all, i don't really regret buying it. I enjoyed my time, but I'd recommend not buying it at full price. €5 seems about right, and that's when you don't consider that you could get games like Tomb Raider and The Witcher 2 for less on sale...

But like I said, the concept is cool, and the music is actually really really good. It's just a shame that it is as shallow as it is.

So yeah. €5 or less? sure, why not, if you need to burn a few hours (and I really do mean a few..)

reviewText: Well this game is just amazing fun.  I saw this on Lirik's stream and fell in love with it.  The soundtrack is outstanding and very relaxing.  I recommend picking up the deluxe edition that comes with the soundtrack.  The game has very chill to moments of pure stress micromanaging your painters.  For people that like to decorate there is quite a bit you can do with that in here as well however going for your favorite textures/furniture may cost you some prestige and draw in the poor folk.  You will see some familiar names in here as well!  Very cool.  I had fun pretending I knew anything about histrory.  Best part about this game for me is there are a lot of games similar to Painters Guild that are micromanagement and once youre done youre done.  Painters Guild has 3 cities as of right now of where you can expand your guild that all reward your work in different ways!  So the replay value is actually pretty high!!!  I absolutely recommend you check this game out.

reviewText:
Painters Guild is a litle flash(? not sure but looks like one) game that can easily cost you a few hours to play. Yet I cant recommend it.

The game itself is pretty shallow, grindy and the end absolutle unsatisfying. You just play until you reach 1620 and then ... here is your highscore you can stop playing now... or go on ... we dont care".

The game itself is pretty shallow as well. You just organize your painters meaning 99% of the time you will simply be rotating them from the sofa/bed to the paintings or to the current training items. The idea of training your painters in different styles and "go with fashion" is interesting enough
date:
only that this mechanic does not work. It takes a painter way to long to change his style and it does not give you that much of a benefit (20% more gold). In the time it takes to change the painting style he could have finished 2-3 paintings and thus earning way more gold than the current style bonus... especially as this changes often faster than the painter can learn new styles.

Other than that there is next to no decision makeing on your part. Furniture? Buy the best your money allows. Painters? Train to 100 skill and swap them between paintings and sofas. Great works (like painting a cathedral) are a nice idea but the mechanic is utterly broken as well. Why? Those works have a top payout of 250 gold and can take 3-6 of your painters away for up to 1 in game year. As a comparison. A single painting worked on for 3 months with 2 painters will net you the nearly same ammount of gold. And the reputation hits you take for turning away customers while doing a great work is not even nearly compensated by the reputation gained from doing the great work.

So in the end the game has some interesting concepts but they all suffer from unbalanced (not broken) mechanics that simply makes those concepts unfun to engage with because they actively punish the player for engaging.

The most effective way of playing is to only spend time and effort on finishing paintings and training painters.

I spend 8 hours with the game and that will probably all the time of my life I spend playing it.

Is that worth the 9
recommended: 99€ asked price? Hell no. I couldnt even recommend getting this at a 50% sale. There is just to litle fun to be had here. There is no strategy no clever thinking required
hoursPlayed: all there is to do is grind grind grind until you reach a boring highscore message.\n\nSorry guys. The only thing nice to say I have for this game
voteText: is that it´s got a nice atmosphere. But even that will wear thin after 5-6 hours."
votesFunny: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
To be honest, I am not sure about this game. It's nice, the pixel graphic matches the style, the music is okay, it starts pretty well. You manage your own little guild by painting for money, hire new talents and expand your house. In-between you build new rooms to hire more people and do contract work in churches. The more prestige you gain, the richer your clients get. Sounds interesting and it is ... at first.

The game could need a few improvements. As some others here already stated, Achievements would be nice. Even better would be more random events. I played under 2 hours and the events repeated itself pretty fast. A bit of a tutorial wouldn't hurt. While playing I had the feeling, that the talents of my hired painters aren't as important as they should be. I also run out of money but always managed to go on, there was no clear punishment (you get some time to earn money, which is fair, but unexpected in a simulation, so I always made my way through).

Beside the negative points, I still recommend the game (Steam really need an not sure"-button)
recommended: because I appreciate the idea and the effort but it wasn't my thing in the end."
voteText: true

reviewText:
Fun management game; time flew by while playing it.
Character editor was pretty robust.
Guild building options were cool, could do with some more options.
Painting system along with the skills, styles etc was deeper than I first realised.
Ways the painters grow, fall sick, get arrested for gambling debts really added to the experience.

Only a few things I'd love to see in future updates:
Relationship system - children would have skills of parents and gives your originally edited character a legacy born through his/her progeny. (Or instead of relationships, you can directly tutor other painters in the guild to develop your skills/traits)
Special requests for paintings as bonus quests - to work alongside the historic moments in the game.
More building/aethetic options/furnature.

reviewText:
This game is a drug! I played seven hours straight, just got up a bit for dinner and came right back to it.
Everything said, it lacks a tutorial and the UI should be a little more responsive and helpful, maybe giving some suggestions via tooltips. In my first game I didn't understand how to sell stuff and got everything a bit cluttered.

The game starts easy enough, but then the ears pass, your guys get old and die, and then the plague strikes, at least it struck me... I almost didn't make it through.

Still, it's a game that teaches you how to pla better, so in my second game I managed to get richer faster and even hire a few famous people.

It's my ideal managerial game, almost perfect!

reviewText: Having completed a full playthrough (Game Years 1460 - 1620) after the v1.071 patch, I can say definitively that you see the entirety of the game after the first hour or two of play.  By Game Year 1520, I had established a successful guild with 9 solid painters (the maximum allowed). The hard
date:
flavorful part of the game was over at that point. For the next 100 years, it was autopilot as the game offered no new challenges, no new rewards, and it drastically reduced the number of historical events mentioned.

Unlike other management games (Grand Prix Story, Game Dev Tycoon, etc.), there doesn't seem to be any replay value. The different bonuses for the different cities are not very impactful after about a half hour of play. Nothing unlocks after a playthrough. The game doesn't offer different paths to explore. There really aren't any decisions or choices to make.

The one part of the game I did not explore was hiring the famous artists that we know today such as Botticelli or Rafael. I have no reason to believe, however, that hiring them open new stories. I suspect that they are simply excellent painters – and I had too many of those.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?list=PLTj9drPC92M2iXZVy0bCpf02SUE8zLaKG&v=rZT7eaq4IpI

This is a summary of my review video, which I encourage you to watch
if you are looking for a more in-depth review.

Painters Guild is a 2d management base building experience with an artistic flair. The options menu is very simplistic, with only the option of full screen or windows mode.  This game walks a fine line in it's methodology of progression. It is entertaining to a point, but once you hit that plateau then it becomes repetitive nonsense with heavy taxation on your resources. If this game is on sale, I would recommend it, but because this game has no true feeling of becoming a legendary artist, only the continuous climb and burden of ownership, management or taxation on your character, there is no feeling of relief or pride in your accomplishment.

It is a time management game, where you accept contracts to create paintings, and have to manage rest for your character, keeping your supplies stocked, and the prestige of your studio. Prestige is the means to lure in higher paying clients- improved by putting out higher quality work, and finishing contracts, as well as improving your home base. You have the capability to hire more people, who have various strengths and weaknesses.

The game is very management oriented, where you build and expand a base, utilize your hired units to ensure growth of the company, and attract higher quality clients that will pay more. In between 30-60 minutes of play, you will reach a plateau in the game, where there are is nothing else to unlock, no more variables that occur. As you build your base larger, the tasks become repetitive. It's a click and drag mentality, the same tasks over and over again.

There is an occasional special project, such as a cathedral, but I've found that the time it takes to complete this task and the numberof people it takes can be more detrimental to your business than not. Most times it's easier to focus on the painting and building aspect rather than focusing on the prestige or special projects.

As you grow larger and become more engulfed into the world, and your prestige  gets higher, you will attract customers with specific requests. This can be potentially disastrous, as it takes years for your characters to get to master status in any one style of artwork and your painters do die throughout the game. If you can't handle the continuous instream, you can end up watching everything you've worked so hard for crumble rapidly in front of you. Artistically this might fall right into the story of an artist, but gameplay wise it doesn't work, for you art does not live on.


Thanks for your viewership and support; for more videos click here:
http:/www.youtube.com/user/SocioPyscho

reviewText:
Please refer to the full Review Video here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Pr_eyzzaJrw

First off, i like the idea and charme behind this game. And in my opinion, it easily could've been something great.
There are however, quite a few big reasons why it fails as a game, to which i am unable to recommend it for this price.

- The sense of progression is totally off. You need way too long to advance.
- There are no new mechanics added to the game as you progress.
- Its always the same 3 cycles: Paint, Sleep, Mix new Paint.
- The game is rendered at 16:10, giving you black bars with 16:9 monitors, no resolutionsettings.
- Various mechanics in the game are absolutely unfair towards the player. (Execution of Sodomites, Upgradepath of Rooms)

For me it feels that the developer definitely is an artist, and i apploud him for the looks of the game, it definitely has its charme. However, when it comes to game-balancing, there are too many things wrong :(

reviewText:
This is a fun management game for art lovers, very educational, with nice classicial music and pixel arts.

Painting style is quite a factor in game as some other down vote reviews ignored, there are furnitures and actions that change artists' style, you can't just keep painting all the time, if your style is wrong, sometimes you'd only receive few Florins and potentially lead your guild to downhill. Also as time progressed the style trend changed, plus you'd have to train young artists and raise older ones to masters, and seeing younger ones surpassed masters is always cool thing, the pace gets fasters as requests keep coming, so this game isn't really shallow with just draw-rest-die cycle.
Even so, it's a game about 'painters', what'd you expect more from it?

I feel the game is a bit easier since update and as devs mentioned at launch they made the game for historical accracy in terms of stories and difficulty, wish later updates could add another difficulty option as devs were going for.

reviewText:
This game is tricky. It may look easy, but it's deceptively so.

You start off with a single painter who needs to train up an apprentice. You quickly learn about the different painting styles while you try to keep your head above the water and throw painting after painting out the door.

Occasionally you get requests to help paint works of art for local buildings, which soon ask for more than just two painters.

So you take on a second apprentice, build out to accomodate them, then a third... and soon you're juggling them all trying to get their skills up, keep the paint flowing, and worry yourself sick about whether your master painter will survive long enough to see their apprentices become master painters themselves.

It's a good game, but if you're expecting a casual approach, you'll soon find you're mistaken. This game gets progressively more difficult to manage.

reviewText:
This is a quaint Pixel-Graphics tycoon-like game. It is fun to watch the progression of your guild and the members within it. That being said, I got about 5 hours of gameplay in and pretty much unlocked everything possible. There also isn't much replayability, so I don't see myself playing this game much in the future unless significant updates are made. I still think it's a fun game and it's worth the playthrough if you're into point-and-click, resource management type games and don't mind paying about $2(USD) per hour of entertainment.

Pros:
- Unique Concept
- Pretty pixel-graphics (if you don't consider that to be an oxymoron...)
- Not very expensive
- Light strategy (maybe a con if you're into very strategic games)

Cons:
- Not much replayability
- Becomes repetative after a few hours
- Possible memory leak (my game was lagging severely toward the last hour or so)

reviewText: Painter's Guild is a cute little managment game. Extra fun if youre into the Italian Renaissance, Art History, or Italian History\n\nI hope this game continues to develop well. I want to feel like part of the world around me but so far, you and your art guild are distant, with no cultural or historic goal to strive for, only money and value related things
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
RIP Alderotto Baldocci, third artist inducted into the Gardetto Guild, who lived to the ripe old age of 75.  The poor guy died as an Apprentice because I forgot to send him on to become a Journeyman and he was already 60 by the time I realised.  He had to watch all the other guild members become Masters around him.


The game can become a little repetetive as it stands, but it doesn't seem geared for long gaming sessions.  There's a real twinge when one of your artists dies.  An hour later you look at their Master work and realise how long they've been gone.  I'd pick it up if you're looking for a neat game to dip into every now and then.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: It's a very simple management game, pixelart as graphics and easy to learn how to play. Althought it doesn't seem to have a deep story, it does goes with through time with historic news... But once you have played through the hours of addicted gameplay, it's probably going to wear off and make you quit the game. Is it worth the 10 €/$? I think so. For what it is, and what you can do, it has given me more satisfaction than other games where I have paid more. I'd rate it a 7/10

reviewText: This game may seem simple at first glance, but when you jump in and play, it is much more than what meets the eye. When I saw this game on steam, I thought it looked like fun, so I bought it and it turns out that it is very fun....if you like managment type games. That was good news for me becasue I love managment simulators and this one seemed unique in the sense that it was set in ancient italy in the 1400's. The pixel art style is simple and works well for this game and the gameplay is very addicting. I recommend picking this game up!

reviewText:
This game is tricky. It may look easy, but it's deceptively so.

You start off with a single painter who needs to train up an apprentice. You quickly learn about the different painting styles while you try to keep your head above the water and throw painting after painting out the door.

Occasionally you get requests to help paint works of art for local buildings, which soon ask for more than just two painters.

So you take on a second apprentice, build out to accomodate them, then a third... and soon you're juggling them all trying to get their skills up, keep the paint flowing, and worry yourself sick about whether your master painter will survive long enough to see their apprentices become master painters themselves.

It's a good game, but if you're expecting a casual approach, you'll soon find you're mistaken. This game gets progressively more difficult to manage.

reviewText:
I really dig this game. The music is cute and appealing, and the simple design of the characters and evironment is exactly what I'd want in a game like this.


It's not a deep, complicated strategic masterpiece. It's a fun, easy enough game to lose a few hours in, it the added appeal of ~~~ART HISTORY~~~  The gameplay, while repetitive after a while, is the desireable click and drag that I was looking when I bought it. I can totally understand why it wouldn't appeal to everyone, but it's exactly what I was after and I would highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys simple management/stretegy games.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
First of all, I saw this game from a youtuber who play this game on his stream and somehow I became interested with this game. However, after several hours of playing this game somehow I reach the point where I have maxed everything that the game can offer ( For example, the number of room I can build, 4-5 people having max stat (100) in the same lifecycle. more than 500 prestige and such). I believed that this game is lacking depth which this games' genre usually gave to their players. It's quite repetitive and it easy to beat this game or felt bored with only 3-4 hours.

Cons:
- There is no in-depth explanation of some stuffs in this game (For example, boosting feature when 2 or more people close with each other. What masterpieces going to benefit us? I try keeping those things for more than 100 years but the price still 200).
- Their website does not provide any support.

My opinion:
In the end, I am regret that I bought this game for $8

reviewText: The Painters Guild is a charming time-managmement game that ultimately is incredibly shallow. The inital impression is good, with cute spritework, but once you get into the rythm of the game there's no sense of progress. Sure your guild gets bigger, but this doesn't increase the challenge, and once you've bought out the meagre furniture shop there's nothing much left to do. Definitely not worth the full price, but if you can get it for less than $5 it's a fun way to spend an afternoon.

reviewText: Amazing concept! A traditional painting themed game is unique thats for sure... but the content is not as much as it could be... if the devs start updating with new content this would be an outstanding game. the sim and managment mechanics are fun as heck and the game mechanics for this genre are simple yet geniously well crafted. the engine could do with some tweeking and upgrading though... good game for its price and definitely worth a shot.

reviewText:
Product received for free

I was sent a key by the developer(s) for review Genuinely, when I first saw this game, I thought it looked amazing, I thought this was going to be the game that gets me back into management simulator games. It kinda did

It wasn't as good as I thought it would be, but since it was made by one person, it's pretty good. There's a couple of bugs that they know about, for example, you can't name your character or guild while being in fullscreen mode, which is a silly little bug that isn't that bad and I haven't come across any other bugs, yet they haven't updated this game even with bug fixes since September 2015.

It doesn't look like they will be updating this anymore, but with it's current state, I think it should be in Early Access on steam, and also think that the price tag is perfect for it.

Brilliant game, but I wish they would updating it a bit.

If you want to see gameplay, check out my YouTube channel with the link below!  Channel
